column7: In 1967$ to ensure that he would never be outranked$ George Washington was awarded the highest military rank that will ever be bestowed: General of the Armies of the United States.
John Adams was the first president to live in the white house.
Thomas Jefferson invented the Moldboard plow$ polygraph copy machine$ spherical sundial$ seven-day-clock$ and macaroni and cheese.
James Madison was 5’4” and less than 100 pounds. He was also the key author of the bill of rights.
James Monroe died on July 4th$ 1831$ exactly five years after both Thomas Jefferson and John Adams.
John Quincy Adams enjoyed skinny dipping in the Potomac.
Andrew Jackson survived 103 duels and was once gifted a 1$400 pound wheel of cheese.
Martin Van Buren’s first language was Dutch$ along with the rest of his hometown of “Old Kinderhook$” which inspired the term O.K.
Despite a strict medical regime of opium and enemas$ William Henry Harrison died after just thirty three days in office.
After vetoing two bills supported by his party$ John Tyler’s entire cabinet resigned except for his Secretary of State.
James K Polk was the first president to have his picture taken.
Zachary Taylor rode into battle sidesaddle and didn’t know he was running for president until weeks after his nomination.
Millard Fillmore ran for president as part of the Know-Nothing party and lost in every state except Maryland.
Franklin Pierce’s only life goal was to be president$ which he did not do well. While leaving office he was asked what he would do next$ his response: “There’s nothing left to do but get drunk.”
James Buchanan raised pygmy goats$ had different colored eyes$ and was the first president to wear blue jeans in the Oval Office.
Lincoln was an accomplished wrestler who was defeated only once in 300 matches$ and has been enshrined in the Wrestling Hall of Fame.
In his youth$ Johnson apprenticed as a tailor$ and even as president he never stopped making his own suits.
Grant was unable to stand the sight of blood$ so much so that he overcook his meat in order to avoid seeing any semblance of blood in it.
Hayes was the only president to be wounded in the Civil War — not once$ but four times.
Not only was Garfield ambidextrous$ he could write Latin with one hand and Greek with the other at the same time.
On his last day in office$ four women offered Arthur their hands in marriage.
Grover Cleveland's epithelium$ a small tumor that was removed from the roof of his mouth$ resides at the Mutter Museum in Philadelphia.
Benjamin Harrison was the first president to have electricity in the White House$ but he was so scared of getting electrocuted that he would never touch the light switches himself.
Grover Cleveland was the only President elected to two nonconsecutive terms.
William McKinley almost always wore a red carnation on his lapel as a good luck charm.
Teddy Roosevelt was shot in an assassination attempt while delivering a speech in Milwaukee$ and he completed the 90-minute speech with the bullet still lodged in his chest.
William Taft$ also known as "Big Bill”$ was the largest president in American history.
Woodrow Wilson's face is on the 100$000 dollar bill
column8: which very few have ever laid hands on.

column7: An advanced student$ Harding earned a Bachelor of Science degree in 1882 at the age of 17.
Calvin Coolidge had a morning ritual in which someone rubbed Vaseline on his head while he ate breakfast in bed.
Hoover was a member of the first class to attend Stanford University from which he graduated with a degree in geology.
Roosevelt was the first President whose mother was allow to vote for him$ and the only president to be elected for four terms.
Before becoming the President of the United States of America$ Harry Truman owned a haberdashery business (a men’s outfitter)$ which went bankrupt in 1921.
Eisenhower banished the White House’s squirrels because they were ruining his putting green.
One of JFK's legs was shorter than the other$ which contributed to his chronic back problems.
President Johnson was famous among White House staffers for having no shame about asking people to follow him into the bathroom to continue conversations as he relieved himself.
Nixon refused to shake hands with anybody from San Francisco.
Ford worked as a fashion model to help pay for law school$ and was featured on the cover of Cosmopolitan magazine and in the pages of Look.
Carter is the only U.S. president to have lived in housing subsidized for the poor.
While modeling for a sculpting class in 1940$ Reagan was deemed as having "the most nearly perfect male figure" by the Division of Fine Arts at the University of Southern California.
During World War II$ Bush flew 58 combat missions for the Navy$ and was awarded three Air Medals and the Distinguished Flying Cross for his service.
When Clinton was in high school$ he played the saxophone in a jazz trio known as the "Three Blind Mice."
In his senior year at high school$ Bush was the head cheerleader of his team.
President Obama applied to appear in a black pin-up calendar while at Harvard but was rejected by the all-female committee.
